title: Protocol for brain-wide or region-specific microglia depletion and repopulation in adult mice
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Inducing widespread depletion and repopulation of microglia
Timing: 3 days
Here we detail how microglial depletion/repopulation can be induced by systemic diphtheria toxin (DT) administration via intraperitoneal (IP) injection into tamoxifen-treated CX3CR1creERT2 × iDTR mice or CX3CR1creERT2 × iDTR × tdTomatoflox mice.
Diphtheria toxin (DT; Sigma-Aldrich) stock solution is prepared at 2 mg/mL in sterile water (e.g., UltraPure water), according to manufacturer’s instructions, and stored at −80°C in 5 μL aliquots. Avoid freeze thawing DT.
The expiration date of the DT stock solution is lot-specific and can be found on the manufacturer’s Certificate of Analysis (Sigma-Aldrich).
Working solutions of DT (3 ng/μL) are made by adding 3 μL of DT stock solution to 2 mL of injectable saline in a 2 mL Eppendorf tube. Vortex the working solution and place on ice.
DT is injected at a dose of 30 ng per gram body weight with 10 μL per gram body weight volume injected; e.g., 20 g mouse will be injected with 200 μL of DT working solution for a 600 ng dose of DT.
To inject working DT solution, mice are weighted and appropriate dose/volume DT working solution loaded into a 1 mL syringe attached to 25-gauge needle.
Restrain the mouse and inject IP with working DT solution. Return the mouse to its home cage.
Mice are injected once daily for three consecutive days, at approximately the same time of day. Microglia should be depleted (>90% depletion) for at least ~24 h after the last DT injection and will undergo endogenous repopulation thereafter. See Troubleshooting 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc1].

Monitor the mice’s weight during DT treatment. Mice should lose no more than 20% of their original body weight over the course of DT treatment. If they do lose greater than 20% of their original body weight, or become sick, then cease DT treatment and monitor mouse’s health.
Critical: Once diluted, DT working solution should be used within 1 h. Always keep DT on ice. Persons working with mice and DT should have a current diphtheria vaccination.
Inducing region-specific depletion/repopulation of hippocampal microglia
Timing: ~30 min per animal
Inducing microglial turnover can also be achieved in a region-specific manner for the hippocampus via stereotaxic intra-hippocampal injection of DT into tamoxifen-treated CX3CR1creERT2 × iDTR mice or tamoxifen-treated CX3CR1creERT2 × iDTR × tdTomatoflox mice using stereotaxic rig (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/321-Fig1.jpg
Figure 1. Setup of stereotaxic rig used for brain injections in mice
Prepare the DT working solution to deliver 0.1 ng of DT in 0.5 μL of sterile saline. Prepare DT working solution just prior to use. Do not freeze-thaw DT.
Attach the Hamilton syringe to the syringe pump (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/321-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. Hamilton syringe attached and held in place to the syringe pump
Fill the Hamilton syringe with sterile saline using a 1 mL syringe (with no needle attached).
Prepare the polyethylene tubing prior to surgery. Insert an 18-gauge needle head (needle only) to the end of the tubing. Secure the needle in place with nail polish. Allow nail polish to harden. UV the tubing and keep the needle sterile.
Prior to attaching to the Hamilton syringe, use an 18-guage needle attached to 1 mL syringe loaded with sterile injectable saline and perfuse saline through the prepared tubing, ensuring that there are no leaks in the tubing and the saline is running through the needle.

Attach the open end of the polyethylene tubing to the Hamilton syringe needle, careful not to puncture holes in tubing. The tubing should be inserted onto the Hamilton syringe by about 0.5 cm to ensure a stable connection (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/321-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Attachment of polyethylene tubing to the Hamilton syringe needle
Connect the tubing with needle end to the stereotaxic rig and gently hold in place with the stereotaxic rig needle attachment. Be careful not to disturb the needle head or dislodge the needle from the tubing (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/321-Fig4.jpg
Figure 4. Tubing with needle end connected to Hamilton syringe held in place to stereotaxic rig
Press the plunger of the Hamilton syringe and expel the sterile saline in the tubing. Carefully remove the droplet from the needle using a sterile tissue or separate sterile 18-guage needle head.
Draw up some air into the tubing then use a sterile 0.6 mL Eppendorf tube lid filled with DT working solution or sterile saline and draw up into the tubing via the needle head of the tubing (Methods Video S1[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc1]). This will allow for a gap (marked with a sharpie) between the sterile saline from the Hamilton syringe and your loaded solution, making it easier to tell whether your solution is indeed be delivered and running through the tubing appropriately. Ensure that there are no bubbles when drawing up the working solution into the tubing (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/321-Fig5.jpg
Figure 5. Tubing filled with working solution to be injected using stereotaxic setup
Anesthetize the mice via IP injection of 0.01 mg/g BW tiletamine/zolazepam (Zoletil) and 0.01 mg/g BW xylazine. Zoletil/xylazine solution is prepared as below:
Using sterile syringe, transfer 0.1 mL of xylazine stock into a 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube.

Add 0.1 mL Zoletil and mix in with 0.1 mL of xylazine by vortex.
Take 0.1 mL of the Zoletil/xylazine stock mixture and put in new 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube.
Add 0.9 mL of injectable saline and mix very well by vortex.
For dosing: use just under 0.1 mL/10 g. For example, for a 20 g mouse, give between 0.18–0.19 mL; for a 30 g mouse give 0.28 mL as a starter. Prepare Zoletil/xylazine mixture either day before surgery (kept in fridge at 4°C for ~8–24 h) or just prior to surgery.
Trim the fur on top of the mouse’s head where the surgery site will be and mount the mouse into the stereotaxic frame.
Coat the mouse’s head with betadine using a cotton tip.
Place eye drops or vaseline to mouse’s eyes to ensure they do not dry out during surgery.
Using a scalpel, make a mid-line incision (1.5 cm long) along the skull, and retract the skin using non-dissolvable sutures to keep the skin away from skull.
Use a surgical marker pen to mark the Bregma location on the skull.
Move the needle to be positioned directly above Bregma and zero the coordinates on the stereotaxic. Raise the needle, so that you do not hit or scrape the skull when moving the needle and move the needle to the required coordinates (X, −2.0 mm; Y, −1.50 mm). Mark this location with the surgical marker. This will be the site to be injected.
Carefully and gently drill out a small hole where the injection site will be. Remove the skull piece carefully with fine forceps. Take great care to not damage the underlying cortex.
Lower the needle to the surface of the cortex. Zero the Z coordinates.

Carefully and slowly lower the needle into the brain over 2 min until you reach -2.0 mm Z coordinates.
Let the needle rest for 3 min.
Start the syringe pump to deliver the solution. Use a flow rate of 0.2 μL/min. For DT we deliver 0.1 ng in 0.5 μL over 2.5 min.
Stop the pump and allow to rest for 3 min.
Slowly draw up the needle. Advance 0.1 mm upward every 30 s for the first 1 mm, then slowly draw up for the remaining 1 mm over another 2–3 min.
Remove the mouse from the stereotaxic frame and place mouse on a heat mat to maintain the animal’s core body temperature.
Suture the incision.
Any type of sutures can be used. We typically use coated Vicryl dissolvable sutures (J493G, J&J, Ethicon).
Monitor the mouse until it has recovered and is awake and walking normally. Return mouse to home cage. Mice should be monitored daily to ensure it has successfully recovered from surgery and the sutures stay intact and the incision site heals.
Note: The coordinates used herein may be adapted to target other brain regions of interest. Here, with the coordinates above we have targeted microglia in the dorsal hippocampus.

Fluorescence activated cell sorting of microglia
Timing: ~1 h 45 min per animal

Below we detail how to isolate resident or repopulated microglia (tdTomato-positive) from the hippocampus of tamoxifen-treated CX3CR1creERT2 × iDTR × tdTomatoflox mice. Mice with resident microglia are administered saline, while DT is administered to induce depletion and endogenous microglia repopulation, as detailed above See Troubleshooting 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.1]. The efficiency of the microglial depletion and repopulation can be assessed by comparing numbers of microglia in microglial depleted animals with vehicle-treated controls (i.e., mice with resident microglia), either via fluorescence activated cell sorting (detailed below), or by immunostaining fixed brain sections with microglial markers (e.g., Iba1).
Mice are euthanized by cervical dislocation and the brains rapidly dissected from skull.
Remove the brain and submerge in ~3 mL of pre-chilled “microglia isolation buffer” in 50 mL falcon tube on ice. An exact volume of pre-chilled “microglia isolation buffer” is not necessary, so long as the brain is fully submerged in the buffer.
In laminar flow hood, transfer brain onto petri dish with drops of ice-cold isolation media (approximately 100–200 μL), and quickly dissect out hippocampus (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/321-Fig6.jpg
Figure 6. Schematic overview of hippocampus dissection
Use surgical blade and cut along optic chiasm to remove rostral region of septo-diencephalon (viewed from bottom of brain)
From the top of the brain, use forceps to separate the hemispheres, and push the hemisphere aside.
Using circular/rolling motion, raise the hippocampus from overlying cortex and carefully remove using curved forceps. Using the forceps, transfer the isolated hippocampus to a separate petri dish.
Keep this isolated hippocampus in drops of ice-cold DMEM F12 with HEPES (~200 μL) in a petri dish on ice until remaining dissections are complete.

Repeat for other hemisphere and/or other brain/s. Use a separate petri dish per sample and keep on ice. Process at most 2 mice/samples per run to ensure that all processing is done as quickly as possible. Samples from multiple mice can be pooled to isolate enough cells for downstream applications.
Using a scalpel blade, gently dice hippocampi in petri dish on ice until no obvious lumps of tissue remain.
Add 0.5 mL of the “papain dissociation buffer” per hippocampi, 0.25 mL onto the minced hippocampi and 0.25 mL on to the side of the petri dish (Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]). Use a 1 mL pipette to aspirate papain and hippocampi and transfer into a 15 mL Falcon tube. Use the extra papain solution on the side of the petri dish to collect any leftover cells/tissue before adding to the same falcon tube.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/321-Fig7.jpg
Figure 7. Papain dissociation buffer added to diced hippocampi in Petri dish
Place the tubes into the 37°C water bath for 8 min.
Remove the tubes from the water bath and using a 1 mL pipette very gently titrate (i.e., pipette up and down) the mixture 3 times by holding the tip of the pipette against side of the tube with some pressure. This step is important to break down any clumps, producing a single cell suspension (Methods Video S2[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc2]).
Return tubes to water bath for another 8 min.
Gently triturate 2 times as above.
Gently add 3–4 mL of warm isolation buffer to tube by adding to side of the tube.
The Isolation buffer is kept warm at 37°C in the water bath.
Centrifuge cells at 300 × g for 10 min.
Aspirate off supernatant, being careful not to disturb pellet.

Re-suspend cells by adding 2 mL of the isolation buffer to the cell pellet using a pipette and gently tapping/flicking the tube.
Filter cells through 40 μm cell sieve (Falcon, BD Biosciences) into FACS tube.
Keep cells on ice and protected from light.
Dissociated single cells are sorted using a Cytopeia Influx Cell Sorter (BD Bioscience).
Microglia sorting strategy is as follows: cells are first defined by their forward scatter vs. side scatter, removing small cellular debris. Single cells are highlighted, and tdTomato-positive cells isolated (Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/321-Fig8.jpg
Figure 8. Representative FACS gating and tdTomato-positive microglia sorting strategy from an uninjured tamoxifen-treated CX3CR1creERT2 × iDTR × tdTomatoflox mouse with resident microglia
For RNA extraction, cells are directly isolated into 300 μL of cell lysis buffer from the Zymo Quick RNA kit in a 1.5 mL RNase-/DNase-free Eppendorf tube. Care should be made to keep the Zymo cell lysis buffer at 22°C–24°C, as the lysis buffer freezes on ice. RNA extraction is performed exactly as according to manufacturer’s instructions (Zymo Research, https://files.zymoresearch.com/protocols/_r1054_r1055_quick-rna_miniprep_kit.pdf[href=https://files.zymoresearch.com/protocols/_r1054_r1055_quick-rna_miniprep_kit.pdf]), completed immediately after cell isolation.
From our experience, we have pooled two ipsilateral hippocampi (i.e., the ipsilateral hippocampi collected from two mice) and we are able to isolate ~40k cells from naive mice, ~20–34k resident microglia cells at 3 days post injury, and ~5–15k repopulating microglia cells at 3 days post injury in a mouse unilateral controlled cortical injury model of moderate traumatic brain injury, as previously described in Willis et al., (2020)[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2]. We have not attempted to isolate the surviving microglia immediately after DT-induced depletion, when the microglia are >90% depleted. Biological replicates can be pooled during FACS isolation prior RNA extraction to generate more RNA, if needed for downstream applications. Troubleshooting 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.3]

Critical: For all steps, ensure to perform in RNase and DNase-free manner, avoiding any fixatives, as this will affect sample quality. Process no more than 2 samples at a time to ensure that all processing is done as quickly as possible. All steps with papain should be done quickly, and papain incubation timed to ensure tissue is appropriately digested.
